relation: This has a new password - value not yet known
pageTitle: Difference between revisions of "Firmware update" - NAS-Central Buffalo - The Linkstation Wiki
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {85383=As of 2005-07-12 Buffalo US has v1.05 and Buffalo Japan has v1.13., 85864=(See Software for details on 2.x firmware. --Fred 14:40, 8 Dec 2005 (CET)), 85694=As of 2005-11-15 Buffalo US has v1.12.}
textBeforeTable: TeraStation Sec spent sleepless nights figuring out these passwords, so all kudos to him. TeraStation Firmware Passwords you can now use the new image.dat instead of the official one to upload your own firmware. adding: tmpimage.tgz Verify password: Enter password: root@linuxbox ~# zip -e image.dat tmpimage.tgz root@linuxbox ~# mv tmpimage-new.tgz tmpimage.tgz root@linuxbox ~# mv tmpimage.tgz tmpimage-old.tgz root@linuxbox ~/fw1.05# cd .. root@linuxbox ~/fw1.05# tar -czf ../tmpimage-new.tgz . You just have to tar/zip/encrypt it again:  root@linuxbox ~/fw1.05# chmod 440 etc/sudoers root@linuxbox ~/fw1.05# chown root:root etc/sudoers EOF admin ALL=(ALL) ALL root@linuxbox ~/fw1.05# cat <<EOF > etc/sudoers or add the sudoers file:  root@linuxbox ~/fw1.05# tar -xz --numeric-owner -p -f ../dropbear.tgz You can now add/change files as you like. e.g. install the [http:/files/dropbear.tgz dropbear] ssh server:  I did that on the TeraStation, where the IDs match anyway, and could use only -xzf.  root@linuxbox ~/fw1.05# tar -xz --numeric-owner -p -f ../tmpimage.tgz root@linuxbox ~# cd fw1.05 root@linuxbox ~# mkdir fw1.05 tmpimage.tgz is the on disk firmware. It can be extracted on any unix sytem, but you should be root to preserve the device-nodes, ownerships and permissions.  inflating: tmpimage.tgz Archive: image.dat user@linuxbox: ~$ unzip -p $PASSWORD image.dat The on disk firmware (image.dat) is much more interesting, but it is an encrypted ZIP file. So all you need is the proper password and you can unzip/decrypt it:  Disk
